# Current Flow

![Electron and conventional current flow](../60-Meta-Attachments/Electron_and_conventional_current_flow.svg)
There are two types of current flows: [conventional current](Conventional-Current) flow and [electron](20220411123012-electron) flow. The [Current](20220408104411-current.md) generated by a **negative charge** moving to the _left_ 等於 the [Current](20220408104411-current.md) generated by a **positive charge** moving to the _right_.

Conventional current flow is from **positive to negative terminal**. It indicates the direction that positive [charges](Charge) would flow.

Electron flow is from **negative to positive terminal**. [Electrons](20220411123012-electron) are negatively charged and are therefore **attracted to the _positive terminal_**.  
![Electron and conventional current flow](../60-Meta-Attachments/242422cab8a4f6f5eef8cda64108609f.jpg)

## Example

> [!example]
> If current flow in one direction is +ve, then it's opposite direction is -ve.
>
> ![a59dc36504638ad604b89c37dff3a0c6](data:image/png;base64,)
>
> - $I_{AB}=-I_{BA}$
> - $I_{1}=-I_{2}$

## Analogy

Just like water flowing through a water pipe.
